item.title: Non-linear Additive Maps
item.description: While teaching an introductory linear algebra course, a colleague noticed that most of the examples of additive maps he gave turned out to be linear. He asked whether I could think of a map which was additive, but not linear. In a general context, the question was to find a ring \(R\), \(R\)-modules \( V\) and \( W\), and a map \( f \colon V \to W\) such that \( f \) is a group homomorphism, but not an \( R\)-module morphism, i.e, \( f(x+y)=f(x)+f(y)\) for all \( x,y \in V,\) but there is some \( r \in R\) and \( z \in V\) such that \( f(r \cdot z) \neq r \cdot f(z)\).
